head.title: Metro Business; Landlords Seek Rise In Rents, Up to 15%

hedline.hl1: Metro Business; Landlords Seek Rise In Rents, Up to 15%

abstract.p: Landlords of one million rent-stabilized apartments in New York City propose rent increase of 9 percent for one-year lease and 15 percent for two-year lease; cite higher operating costs (S)

block.p: Landlords of the one million rent-stabilized apartments in New York City yesterday proposed a rent increase of 9 percent for a one-year lease and 15 percent for a two-year lease. They cited higher operating costs, notably the price of fuel oil for heat and hot water.

''Significant inflationary pressures are building,'' said Jack Freund, vice president of the Rent Stabilization Association, a landlords' group. It will detail its position at a hearing today before the city's Rent Guidelines Board. The board has scheduled a preliminary vote for Monday on the maximum rent increases on stabilized apartments for leases renewed in the year starting Oct. 1.

Landlords of the one million rent-stabilized apartments in New York City yesterday proposed a rent increase of 9 percent for a one-year lease and 15 percent for a two-year lease. They cited higher operating costs, notably the price of fuel oil for heat and hot water.

''Significant inflationary pressures are building,'' said Jack Freund, vice president of the Rent Stabilization Association, a landlords' group. It will detail its position at a hearing today before the city's Rent Guidelines Board. The board has scheduled a preliminary vote for Monday on the maximum rent increases on stabilized apartments for leases renewed in the year starting Oct. 1.

The debate over rent is intensifying this year, after a long period of modest increases. For five of the last six years, the board has approved increases of 2 percent for a one-year lease and 4 percent for a two-year lease.

But last week, the board released its annual study of the landlords' operating costs, showing a rise of 7.8 percent. At the same time, the board's chairman, Edward S. Hochman, proposed changes in the rent formula that could result in increases of 8.5 percent for a one-year lease and 12 percent for a two-year lease, although he said he did not expect those numbers to be adopted.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who appoints the rent board, called those numbers ''very, very high'' and stressed that no decisions had been made.
